sec.title: Clinical History
sec.p: A 60-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the hospital because of mild right lumbar pain. An abdominal computed tomography scan disclosed a round solid nodule in the right adrenal gland. A laparoscopic resection of the tumor was carried out.

A large, black, almost spherical tumor that weighed 10 g and measured 3.5 × 3 × 2.5 cm was received in the pathology laboratory. On cut section the tumor displayed a solid, uniformly black surface (Figures 1 and 2). Histologically, the lesion was composed of cords of adrenal cortical cells with regular round to oval nuclei and an eosinophilic cytoplasm containing numerous brown pigmented granules (Figures 3-5).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The differential diagnosis of a dark brown to black mass in the adrenal gland includes myelolipoma, primary and secondary melanoma, hemangioma, hematoma, and so-called black (pigmented) adenoma, the latter being the subject of this presentation.
Early descriptions of pigmented adenomas of the adrenal gland are those of Baker in 1938,1 Luthers in 1953,2 and Macadam in 1971.3

In an autopsy study of 100 consecutive autopsies carried out in 1972, Robinson et al found 37 cases of pigmented adrenal cortical nodules ranging in diameter from 1 mm to 1.5 cm.4 Grossly, they were usually sharply circumscribed but not encapsulated.4 Most were brown to black in color to the naked eye, and most of them were centered at the corticomedullary junction. Some cases extended into the medulla but the majority extended into the cortex.4

Black adenoma of the adrenal gland appears to arise from the compact granulated cells of the zona reticularis and from those at the interface between this layer and the fasciculata zone.3 The normal reticular layer is known to include compact cells containing residual bodies that represent lysosomes with granular lipid pigment.4

The nature of the cytoplasmic granules of black adenoma has been extensively studied. Initially, it was assumed that they represented neuromelanin granules.5 Ultrastructural and histochemical analysis revealed that the granular pigment was instead composed of lipofuscin. This is a naturally occurring lipochrome, the product of lipid peroxidation, which is contained predominantly in lysosomes and present in organs involved in lipid metabolism. Its deposition is an age-related phenomenon. However, lipofuscin accumulation does not begin in old age but starts very early, the granules increasing in number and size with age.3

It would thus appear that these pigmented adrenal nodules represent nests of zona reticularis cells with a high cytoplasmic content of lipofuscin.4 This pigment is commonly observed in both the adrenal cortex and medulla. It tends to concentrate at the corticomedullary junction and increases with age.4

It is unclear whether these collections of pigmented cells represent hyperplasia or neoplasia.4 Actually, at least some of these lesions may be the result of a peculiar condensation of pigmented cells that are neither hyperplastic nor neoplastic.4 The pigmented reticular layer cells are normally found in the aging adrenal and the pigmented nodules may simply be an area of concentrated pigmented reticular layer cells due to alterations in the metabolism of lipoproteins leading to an imbalance between pigment formation and excretion from the cells.6-9 Some authors have equated these pigmented nodules to the nodular transformation commonly seen in other endocrine organs.

The majority of these black adenomas lack endocrine activity, but cases have been seen associated with Cushing’s syndrome,8,10-12 primary aldosteronism,13,14 and renal failure due to analgesic nephropathy.3 Therefore, whenever this lesion is encountered, a careful search should be made for clinical manifestations of adrenal cortical hormone excess.
